channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia Targets Power, Water and Heat for Ukraine’s Civilians
item.description: The stepped-up attacks on cities, including through the heavy use of Iranian-made exploding drones, threaten a new sort of humanitarian crisis for Ukrainians this winter.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers on Monday combed though the rubble of a building in Kyiv, Ukraine, that was hit by an exploding drone.

item.title: Italy’s Next Government Hinges on a Familiar Face: Silvio Berlusconi
item.description: Giorgia Meloni’s likely turn as prime minister will depend on support from the billionaire media mogul. So may the health of Italian democracy.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

item.title: As Europe Piles Sanctions on Russia, Some Sacred Cows Are Spared
item.description: The European Union has been severing economic ties with Moscow to support Ukraine, but some countries have lobbied to protect key sectors.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Virginie Nguyen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rough diamonds, a lucrative export for Russia, are shipped to the Belgian city of Antwerp, an important diamond hub.

item.title: Strikes Spread in France, Piling Pressure on Macron
item.description: Students and transit workers joined a walkout that started at oil refineries. The unrest is a growing problem for President Emmanuel Macron, whose government was already embattled in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Protesters in Paris holding a white sign reading “General anger, total strike” during a nationwide strike.

item.title: Liz Truss’s New Economic Agenda Looks a Lot Like the Labour’s
item.description: After a blowback over her budget-busting tax cuts, Britain’s prime minister has junked her free-market plans and adopted several measures favored by Labour.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Liz Truss took over the Conservative Party as a free-market evangelist in the vein of Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan.

item.title: Iranian Climber Elnaz Rekabi Competes Without Hijab, Sparking Fear
item.description: Elnaz Rekabi flew back to Iran on Tuesday after competing in an international climbing competition without her hijab — breaching the Islamic Republic’s rules for women athletes.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Rhea Kang/Agence France-Presse, via International Federation of Sport Climbing
item.media:description: Elnaz Rekabi competing at the Asian Championships in Seoul, in a photo provided by the International Federation of Sport Climbing.

item.title: Germany’s Cybersecurity Chief Removed Over Alleged Ties to Russia
item.description: The allegations of possible ties to Russian intelligence were reported this month by a German satirical news show.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: ZDF Magazin Royale reported that Arne Schönbohm kept contact with a lobbying group he co-founded a decade ago that included at least one Russian cybersecurity firm.

item.title: Australia Reverses Recognition of West Jerusalem as Israel’s Capital
item.description: The move rescinded a 2018 decision to recognize Israeli sovereignty in West Jerusalem. It drew barbs from Israel and praise from Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Myra Noveck and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The status of West Jerusalem has become a source of contention in American and Australian politics.

item.title: New Crack in Apple’s Armor as Dozens Strike at Its Stores in Australia
item.description: The uprising will be of keen interest in the U.S., where a second Apple store voted to unionize last week.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: An Apple Store in Sydney, Australia, in 2020. Strikes in the country’s retail sector are rare.

item.title: Drones Embody an Iran-Russia Alliance Built on Hostility to the U.S.
item.description: Authoritarian regimes in Moscow and Tehran have in common international isolation, domestic crisis and conflict with the West.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: A drone believed to be an Iranian Shahed-136 nearing its target in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Ukrainians Struggle to Conserve Energy After Strikes Damage Power Stations
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said that 30 percent of Ukraine’s power stations were “destroyed” in the past eight days, causing “massive blackouts across the country.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising on the outskirts of Kyiv, Ukraine, during a Russian missile attack on Tuesday.

item.title: China Recruiting Former R.A.F. Pilots to Train Army Pilots., U.K. Says
item.description: Citing national security, Britain wants to stop its retired military pilots from accepting lucrative contracts to train members of the People’s Liberation Army.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: A J-16 fighter jet at a training base for the People’s Liberation Army in Ningbo, China, last year. China has contracted with as many as 30 retired British military pilots to train its crews, an official said.

item.title: Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt Drops Most of U.K. Tax-Cut Plan
item.description: Jeremy Hunt, the new finance minister, dropped almost all of Ms. Truss’s planned cuts, a deeply humbling reversal for Ms. Truss.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The statement by Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, Jeremy Hunt, laid bare a government forced into a humiliating 180-degree turn in its economic policy.

item.title: France Returned 24 Skulls to Algeria. They Weren’t What They Seemed.
item.description: The restitution of the remains, said to belong to 19th-century freedom fighters, was hailed as a symbol of reconciliation, but papers obtained by The Times reveal a gesture muddled by politics.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The Algerian flag draped over coffins containing the 19th-century remains of people who were said to have been freedom fighters. The bones were returned to Algeria by France in 2020.

item.title: South Korean Super App Kakao Goes Down, Putting a Halt on Life
item.description: A days-long outage at Kakao has led to the resignation of a co-CEO and a reckoning over Big Tech’s extensive grip over the South Korean economy.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: The co-chiefs of Kakao. Namkoong Whon, left, and Hong Eun-taek, right, during a news conference at Kakao’s office in Pangyo, South Korea, on Wednesday.

item.title: Waiting for Refugee Status, Thousands Live in Limbo
item.description: As the Biden administration prioritizes resettling people fleeing Ukraine and Afghanistan, many other refugees are waiting years in a system struggling to rebuild.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Feroza Binti Abdul Rashid, a Rohingya refugee, and her 5-year-old daughter at their home in Milwaukee. Her husband has not been able to join the family in the United States.

item.title: Britain Scales Back Foreign Aid, Threatening Progress in Global Health
item.description: The nation is often the second-largest donor to groups working in poor countries to prevent and treat infectious diseases, and to provide reproductive health services to women.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
item.media:description: A shipment of medical supplies, sent from the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office in Britain, arriving in New Delhi last year.

item.title: South Korea Gets Squeezed Between the US and China
item.description: The intensifying rivalry between Washington and Beijing is causing jitters in South Korea, where security ties and economic priorities are not always aligned.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents and protesters blocked a road to the nearby Thaad base in Soseong-ri, South Korea, in September

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Russian attacks on Ukrainian power stations.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: An 87-year-old woman wept on Tuesday as she recalled surviving a Russian missile strike on the house next door in Kupiansk last week. Her home was heavily damaged.

item.title: Where Have All the Men in Moscow Gone?
item.description: Across the capital, there are noticeably fewer men at restaurants, stores and social gatherings. Many have been called up to fight in Ukraine. Others have fled to avoid being drafted.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

item.title: Brittney Griner Releases Message on Her Birthday to Thank Her Supporters
item.description: The basketball star’s lawyers said they had met with her for several hours on Tuesday and relayed messages from well-wishers.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Downes, Valerie Hopkins, Michael Crowley and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, who has been detained in Russia since February, in Khimki, Russia, in August.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Airstrikes Cripple Ukraine’s Power Stations
item.description: Plus what’s at stake in the U.S. midterms and what China’s delay in releasing economic data means
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hard and Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: People shopping in a supermarket as Kharkiv suffers an electricity outage in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Iran Sends Drone Trainers to Crimea to Aid Russian Military
item.description: The trainers from Iran’s paramilitary wing have been deployed to help Russia overcome mechanical problems with the fleet.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest outside the Iranian Embassy in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Denmark Says ‘Powerful Explosions’ Caused Nord Stream Pipeline Leaks
item.description: The findings were similar to those of Swedish investigators, who reported this month that the leaks were the result of detonations that they strongly suspected were acts of sabotage.
item.dc:creator: Jasmina Nielsen and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Danish Defense Command, via Agence France-Press — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo from Sept. 29 shows gas leaking from one of the damaged Nord Stream pipelines in the Baltic Sea.

item.title: Power in the N.F.L.
item.description: The owner of the Washington Commanders has survived numerous allegations in the image-conscious N.F.L.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas
item.media:credit: Geoff Burke/USA Today Sports, via Reuters

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Russian drones have exploded over Kyiv, killing at least four people.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers at a residential building in Kyiv that was struck by a Russian drone attack early Monday morning.

item.title: Russia Unleashes More Drones on Kyiv, Sowing Fear and Bringing Death
item.description: “What a horror,” said a Ukrainian retiree, as plumes of smoke rose from a central Kyiv street. “Again!” she said. “This is now happening all the time.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Megan Specia, Maria Varenikova and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from the site of an explosive drone strike in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Kyiv is Attacked by Iranian-Made Drones
item.description: Plus China delays economic data and the U.K. finance minister drops the tax plan.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hard and Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers comb through the rubble of a residential building that was hit by an explosive drone sent by Russia in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Russia threatens to block an extension of the Ukraine grain deal.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: Nord Vind, a Barbados-flagged ship that left Ukraine, anchored in Istanbul for a grain analysis last week.

item.title: Rightist Party in Sweden Gets No Formal Role but Big Say in Government
item.description: The anti-immigrant Sweden Democrats will have a say over new policies for the incoming government under a complicated leadership agreement.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson
item.media:description: Ulf Kristersson, who will be Sweden’s new prime minister, in Parliament in Stockholm on Monday.

item.title: A Military Jet Crashed in Southern Russia, Killing At Least Four
item.description: Russian military officials said the jet had been on a training flight when one of its engines caught fire, causing it to crash in a port town about 25 miles from Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Randy Pennell and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: The site of a plane crash at a residential building in the southern city of Yeysk, Russia, on Monday.

item.title: Nigeria Floods Kill Hundreds and Displace Over a Million
item.description: The country is experiencing its worst floods in years, damaging homes, infrastructure and vast sections of farmland.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: Vehicles on an unflooded road in Lokoja, Nigeria, on Oct. 13. The floods have partly or wholly destroyed farmland, infrastructure and 200,000 homes.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia exchange prisoners, many of them women.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky

item.title: Crude Comments From Europe’s Top Diplomat Point to Bigger Problems
item.description: Josep Borrell Fontelles said Europe was “a garden,” and the world “a jungle,” triggering charges of neocolonialism and racism just as the E.U. tries to drum up support in the developing world.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: The European Union’s top diplomat, Josep Borrell Fontelles, on Saturday in Berlin. Recent comments by Mr. Borrell have been widely denounced.

item.title: Resilient Kyiv Patches Up After Attacks, but Some Things Can’t Be Fixed
item.description: After a barrage of Russian missile and drone strikes on the Ukrainian capital, its residents show a resolve to clean up and press on.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke billows from the site of a drone attack as passengers walk with their luggage from nearby train and bus stations in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Protester Is Dragged Into a Chinese Consulate in England and Beaten
item.description: The scuffle came as tensions have escalated between Beijing and London, which has offered special visas to Hong Kongers seeking to leave.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Matthew Leung/The Chaser News, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A British police officer intervenes in a scuffle between a protester, center, and consulate staff during a demonstration at the Chinese Consulate in Manchester, England, on Sunday.

item.title: BTS Members to Enlist in South Korea’s Military
item.description: Ending months of debate, the band’s label said that the seven members would serve their military conscriptions. They plan to reunite in a couple of years.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Bright Music, via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: BTS performing in Busan, South Korea, on Saturday, the band’s first concert in months.

item.title: Mayor Says Moscow Has Reached Its Draft Quota
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced what he called a partial mobilization of troops on Sep. 21. Defense officials had said Russia would aim to draft about 300,000 civilians.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Russian conscripted men saying goodbye to relatives at a recruiting office in Moscow earlier this month.

item.title: Generators Switch Back On at Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant After Russian Strike
item.description: A Russian strike again disconnected the embattled plant from the national power grid, forcing it to move to backup power, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A blast on Monday morning disconnected the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant from external power sources.

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene’s Comeback
item.description: Republican leaders have embraced the former political pariah, demonstrating Trumpism’s hold over the party.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marjorie Taylor-Greene.

item.title: What We Know About the Iranian-Made Drones Russia Is Using in Ukraine
item.description: Russia has used the drones to strike on the battlefield and in Ukrainian cities. Their use may be a sign that Moscow is running low on precision-guided weapons.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pedestrians walked past wreckage from an explosive drone attack in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Is This the World’s Most Picturesque High Dive?
item.description: Catch a glimpse of a storied tradition in Bosnia and Herzegovina, where, for hundreds of years, divers have leaped from a bridge in the southern city of Mostar.
item.dc:creator: Alessio Mamo and Marta Bellingreri

item.title: At least two drones appeared to target a city heating station in central Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: The aftermath of a drone strike in central Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: A week after a round of strikes, Kyiv’s people take cover again.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Megan Specia and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: Smoke rising from a building in Kyiv on Monday, after explosions rocked the Ukrainian capital.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Troubles with Russia’s draft.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian conscripts at army games in the Moscow region in August. Russia struggled with training even before September’s draft, experts said.

item.title: Here’s what we know about the attacks on Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Megan Specia and Austin Ramzy

item.title: Iran’s Loyal Security Forces Protect Ruling System That Protesters Want to Topple
item.description: The Revolutionary Guards — the country’s most powerful military force — have become so deeply woven into Iran’s economy and power structure that they have everything to lose if the system falls.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: The Revolutionary Guards, a force with hundreds of thousands of members, is separate from the national army and is charged specifically with defending the ruling system.

item.title: Strikes Hit Staging Ground for Troops in Russia’s Border Region
item.description: Explosions rocked Belgorod and the city of Donetsk on Sunday, signaling that the mayhem unleashed by Russia’s invasion is spreading far beyond the front lines.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins, Megan Specia and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A government building in the Russian-controlled city of Donetsk that was heavily damaged in an attack on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: China’s Leader Warns of ‘Stormy Seas’
item.description: Plus explosions in the Russian city of Belgorod and a fire at a notorious prison in Iran.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Russian troops have started to arrive in Belarus.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus in Dushanbe, Tajikistan, last week.

item.title: Russia’s Draft Sends Barely Trained Men to War in Ukraine
item.description: Newly mobilized recruits are already at the front in Ukraine, a growing chorus of reports says, fighting and dying after only days of training.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian conscripts at army games in the Moscow region in August. Russia struggled with training even before September’s draft, experts said.

item.title: Tens of Thousands March in Paris to Protest Rising Living Costs
item.description: The demonstration occurred on the heels of strikes at oil refineries, adding to a tense political atmosphere.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters in Paris on Sunday.

item.title: How Ukraine’s Surrogate Mothers Have Survived the War
item.description: When Russia invaded, Ukraine’s once-booming surrogacy industry seemed at risk of collapsing. But surrogate mothers and agencies have managed to continue deliveries, and clients are arriving again to pick up their children.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova, Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: China’s Leader Xi Hails His Rule as He Prepares to Expand Power
item.description: Xi Jinping is expected to secure a third term as leader during a pivotal meeting of the Communist Party, extending his authoritarian rule over the country.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher, Vivian Wang and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China on Sunday at the opening ceremony of the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

item.title: Macron the Disrupter Seeks Direction
item.description: He wants to lead a united Europe to independence. But the world has changed on him.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France at the United Nations General Assembly last month.
